conclusion: The initial light source is positioned above the objects, causing their respective shadows (A, B, C, and D) to be cast onto the ground.
The light source moves to the back left above the objects.
When the light source moves to the back left, it will cast shadows in a direction opposite to its new position relative to each object.
Object A was casting shadow A initially. Moving the light source to the back left will result in shadow A moving towards the front right.
Object B was casting shadow B initially. Moving the light source to the back left will result in shadow B moving towards the front right.
Object C was casting shadow C initially. Moving the light source to the back left will result in shadow C moving towards the front right.
Object D was casting shadow D initially. Moving the light source to the back left will result in shadow D moving towards the front right.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all move towards the front right due to the new position of the light source.
Shadows are created where light does not reach, and this is determined by the angle between the light source and the objects.
As the light source shifts to the back left, the shadows will shift correspondingly to the front right.
